'''Gotham''' is a family of geometric [[sans-serif]] digital typefaces designed by American type designer [[Tobias Frere-Jones]] in 2000. Gotham's letterforms are inspired by a form of architectural [[signage]] that achieved popularity in the mid-twentieth century, and are especially popular throughout [[New York City]].<ref name="Gotham">{{cite web|url=http://www.typography.com/fonts/font_history.php?historyItemID=1&productLineID=100008|title=Gotham:History|publisher=Hoefler & Frere-Jones|accessdate=2009-01-25}}</ref>
Since creation, Gotham has been highly visible due to its appearance in many notable places, including a large amount of campaign material created for [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|Barack Obama's 2008 presidential campaign]], as well as the cornerstone of the [[One World Trade Center]], the tower to be built on the site of the former [[World Trade Center]] in New York.
==Creation and style== The Gotham font was initially commissioned by ''[[GQ]]'' magazine, whose editors wanted to display a sans-serif with a "geometric structure" that would look "masculine, new, and fresh" for their magazine. Although the magazine was initially considering a series of fonts that either looked like techno CD covers or were more traditional like [[Futura (typeface)|Futura]], they agreed that they needed something "that was going to be very fresh and very established to have a sort of credible voice to it," according to [[Jonathan Hoefler]].<ref name="helvetica-film">{{cite web|url=http://www.helveticafilm.com/newblog/2008/02/19/a-font-we-can-believe-in/|title=A Font You Can Believe In|last=Hustwit|first=Gary|date=2 February 2008|publisher=HelveticaFilm.com|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
Frere-Jones' inspiration for the typeface came from time spent walking block-by-block through [[Manhattan]] with a camera to find source material,<ref name="morning-news"/> and he based the font on the lettering seen in older buildings, especially the sign on the Eighth Avenue facade of the [[Port Authority Bus Terminal]]. "I suppose there's a hidden personal agenda in the design," Frere-Jones said, "to preserve those old pieces of New York that could be wiped out before they're appreciated. Having grown up here, I was always fond of the 'old' New York and its lettering."<ref name="morning-news">{{cite web|url=http://www.themorningnews.org/archives/personalities/is_gotham_the_new_interstate.php|title=Is Gotham the New Interstate?|last=Siegel|first=Dimitri|date=8 August 2002|publisher=[[The Morning News (online magazine)|The Morning News]]|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
The lettering that inspired this typeface originated from the style of 1920s era sans-serifs like [[Futura (typeface)|Futura]], where "Type, like architecture, like the organization of society itself, was to be reduced to its bare, efficient essentials, rid of undesirable, local or ethnic elements." This theme was found frequently in Depression-era type in both North America and Europe, particularly Germany.<ref name="werner">{{cite journal|url=http://www.aiga.org/content.cfm/freedom-tower-type|title=Freedom Tower Type|last=Werner|first=Paul T.|date=16 July 2004|journal=AIGA Journal of Design|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> This simplification of type is characterized by Frere-Jones as "not the kind of letter a type designer would make. It's the kind of letter an engineer would make. It was born outside the type design in some other world and has a very distinct flavor from that."<ref name="helvetica-film"/>
Reviews of Gotham focus on its identity as something both American and specific to New York City. According to David Dunlap of ''[[The New York Times]]'', Gotham "deliberately evokes the blocky no-nonsense, unselfconscious architectural lettering that dominated the [New York] streetscape from the 1930's through the 1960's."<ref name="times-dunlap">{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2004/07/08/nyregion/08blocks.html|title=9/11 Cornerstone, Chiseled With a New York Accent|last=Dunlap|first=David|date=8 July 2004|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> Andrew Romano of ''[[Newsweek]]'' concurs. "Unlike other sans serif typefaces, it's not German, it's not French, it's not Swiss," he said. "It's very American."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.newsweek.com/blogs/stumper/archive/2008/02/27/how-obama-s-branding-is-working-on-you.aspx|title=Expertinent: Why the Obama "Brand" Is Working|last=Romano|first=Andrew|date=27 February 2008|publisher=Newsweek|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
According to Frere-Jones, Gotham wouldn't have happened without the ''GQ'' commission. "The humanist and the geometric ... had already been thoroughly staked out and developed by past designers. I didn't think anything new could have been found there, but luckily for me (and the client), I was mistaken."<ref name="morning-news"/>
==On the Freedom Tower== Gotham was prominently featured in 2004 as the typeface on the cornerstone for the [[One World Trade Center|Freedom Tower]] at the [[World Trade Center]] site, itself owned by the [[Port Authority of New York and New Jersey]], which also owns the bus terminal that inspired the typeface. In a [[Independence Day (United States)|Fourth of July]] speech at its unveiling, then-Governor [[George Pataki]] cited the cornerstone as the "bedrock of our state". The text is written in all-uppercase letters, which was criticized, as some wanted a mix of upper and lower-case to "give the words a human voice."<ref name="times-dunlap"/>
==In the Obama campaign== [[File:Change We Can Believe In.svg|frame|right|Gotham as featured in the Obama '08 campaign slogan]] Original materials for the [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|Obama campaign]] used the serif [[Perpetua (typeface)|Perpetua]]. Later, however, upon hiring [[John Slabyk]], and Scott Thomas, the campaign made the change to Gotham, and the font was used on numerous signs and posters for the campaign.<ref name="Doctor">{{cite web|url=http://media.www.ricethresher.org/media/storage/paper1290/news/2008/11/07/Election08/Campaign.Messages.Marked.By.Typography-3530592.shtml|title=Campaign messages marked by typography|last=Doctor|first=Eric|date=7 November 2008|publisher=The Rice Thresher|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
The ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'' praised the choice for its "potent, if unspoken, combination of contemporary sophistication (a nod to his suits) with nostalgia for America's past and a sense of duty."<ref name="BrandObama">{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/04/arts/04iht-design7.html|title=Brand Obama, a leader in the image war|last=Rawsthorn|first=Alice|date=6 April 2008|publisher=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=2011-02-19}}</ref> John Berry, an author of books on typography, agreed: "It's funny to see it used in a political campaign because on the one hand it's almost too ordinary yet that's the point. It has the sense of trustworthiness because you've seen it everywhere."<ref name="LA-times">{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/mar/30/image/ig-font30|title=The Character Issue|last=Tschorn|first=Adam|date=2 April 2008|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> Graphic designer [[Brian Collins (designer)|Brian Collins]] noted that Gotham was the "linchpin" to Obama's entire campaign imagery.<ref name="To the Letter Born">{{cite web|url=http://campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com/tag/gotham-typeface/|title=To the Letter Born|last=Heller|first=Steven|date=2 April 2008|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
Observers of the [[Democratic Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2008|primary]] and general elections compared Obama's design choices favorably to those made by his opponents. In her campaign, [[Hillary Clinton]] used [[New Baskerville]], a serif used by book publishers, law firms, and universities, while [[John McCain]] used [[Optima]], the same font used for the [[Vietnam Veterans Memorial]].<ref name="BrandObama" /><ref name="Non-Fontogenic">{{cite web|url=http://www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=79|title=...and Non-Fontogenic...|date=21 February 2008|publisher=Hoefler & Frere-Jones|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> It also has to be noticed that while the Obama campaign material still used the [[Perpetua (typeface)|Perpetua typeface]], the short-lived [[John Edwards]] campaign was already using Gotham Ultra.<ref name="A Change We Made">{{cite web|url=http://www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=63|title=A Change We Made|date=4 January 2008|publisher=Hoefler & Frere-Jones|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref>
After Obama won the presidency, Gotham and similar typefaces found their way into various federal government projects, most notably the identity of the [[2010 United States Census]].
==Notable examples== Gotham has found its way into other commercial media, as well. [[Coca-Cola]], television shows [[Maury (TV series)|''Maury'']] and ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', the [[Tribeca Film Festival]], the [[Qwest]] advertisements, and the [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] Governor's Office of Customer Service have all used Gotham in logos.<ref name="Doctor"/> The Georgia state government cited Gotham's "clean, fresh lines" and variations that "offer a variety of options for use in all marketing, advertising and signage applications" as reason for its use.<ref name="georgia">{{cite web|url=http://team.georgia.gov/OCS/OCS_CommonFiles/OCS_Files/CS_Branding.pdf|title=Governor's Office of Customer Service Brand Standards Manual|publisher=Georgia Governor's Office of Customer Service|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> [[Starbucks]] used the typeface in conjunction with the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 Presidential election]] to advertise an offer of free coffee to people who vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whywhywhywhywhy.com/2008/11/starbucks-using-gotham-typeface-to-endorse-obama/|title=Starbucks Using Gotham Typeface to Endorse Obama?|last=Neale|first=McDavitt Van Fleet|date=3 November 2008|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a2J8KJDsqqY|title=If you vote, Starbucks buys your coffee|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=2009-01-25}}</ref> Gotham has also been used by [[Yahoo!|Yahoo's]] website as well as [[The Criterion Collection]]'s.
Gotham has also been used by [[Rite Aid|Rite Aid Pharmacy]], [[Banana Republic]], [[Crest (toothpaste)|Crest]] dental hygiene products, and [[Smirnoff]] Cocktails.
The Malaysian [[Astro (satellite TV)|Astro]] network uses Gotham for most of its text.
Frere-Jones said about the typeface when it was released in 2002: "With Gothamâs originâand my own stubborn opinionsâI think that anywhere in the suburban sprawl would be the worst place for it: advertising for featureless subdivisions, the specials board at the Exit 23 [[Dairy Queen]], bumper stickers that say âI [heart] my SUVâ and so on."<ref name="morning-news" />
* Gotham is the brand font for [[Tom Ford]], [[Yahoo!]], and [[ZipRealty]].
* Gotham is the font used in the [[Chicago 2016 Olympic bid|Chicago 2016 Summer Olympic Games Bid]].
* Gotham is used in new logo of TV channels [[Discovery Channel]] and [[HGTV]], and branding for [[QVC]], [[USA Network]] and [[History Channel]].
* A modified version of Gotham Ultra is used by [[Cartoon Network]] for its new logo and for presentation.
* The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] uses Gotham for its on-screen typographic identity, beginning with the graphic refresh of [[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] bulletins on [[ABC1]] and the launch of [[ABC News 24]] on 22 July, 2010.
* Gotham is used for the titles to Christopher Nolan's film ''[[Inception]]'', Duncan Jones' ''[[Moon (film)|Moon]]'', David O. Russell's ''[[The Fighter (2010 film)|The Fighter]]'', and Tom Ford's film ''[[A Single Man (film)|A Single Man]]''.
* Gotham has been used for Nickelodeon's presentations on TV.
* Gotham has been used for the John Hampden Grammar School's, High Wycombe, United Kingdom stationery
* Gotham was used for the popular ''I'm With Coco'' posters during [[Conan O'Brien]]'s [[2010 Tonight Show conflict]]. The font was eventually adopted for [[TBS (TV channel)|TBS]]'s ''[[Conan (TV series)|Conan]]'' logo.
* Gotham has been used for [[BBC Sport]] television programmes' on-screen graphics since the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].
* Gotham is used in the logos of Austrian national broadcaster [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]].
A customized version of Gotham is the font used for the new logo of [[United Continental Holdings]], replacing the previous font of [[Continental Airlines]], called [[Perpetua (typeface)|Monotype Perpetua]] and the corporate font of [[United Airlines]].
==Variations== Gotham originally was introduced with an italic as well as a range of widths.<ref name="Gotham" /> In 2007, a Rounded variant was introduced due to a commission from [[Print (magazine)|''Print'']] magazine.<ref name="Typographica-Rounded">{{cite web|url=http://typographica.org/2007/on-typography/gotham-rounded-corners-cut-by-popular-demand/|title=Gotham Rounded: Corners Cut by Popular Demand|date=10 January 2007|publisher=Typographica|accessdate=2009-01-21}}</ref> In 2009, Hoefler and Frere-Jones introduced new Narrow and Extra Narrow versions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=165|title=THE NEW GOTHAMS: 46 New Fonts from H&FJ|date=20 January 2009|publisher=Hoefler & Frere-Jones|accessdate=2009-01-25}}</ref> On April 4, 2011, Hoefler and Frere-Jones announced that they had created a new custom version of Gotham with serifs for the use of President Barack Obama's 2012 campaign. In announcing the news they wrote: "Can We Add Serifs to Gotham? For the President of The United States? Yes We Can.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hoefler|first=Jonathan|title=Can We Add Serifs to Gotham?|url=http://www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=261|publisher=H&FJ News|accessdate=14 April 2011}}</ref>
